ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: This class immersed me in the world of medicine, while simultaneously immersing me in the Spanish language. Profesora does a wonderful job of covering a wide variety of key terms and ensuring retention.
Learned some stuff about medicine I guess. Mostly nothing.
spanish for the medical professions
I learned vocabulary and the basic ideas around general medical issues.
spanish
I learned very little but the class was fun.
i learned medical terminology in spanish
Medical Spanish vocabulary & how to deal with and diagnose common illnesses
I learned about a general introduction into Medicine!

Profesora Carerrass class helped me become a much better reader, writer, and speaker in Spanish. Her class also provides a unique opportunity to learn about current topics in biology and medicine through the lens of the Spanish-speaking world, using real-world primary sources written in Spanish for Spanish speakers. Im so grateful that I had the opportunity to take this class and would absolutely recommend it to any student interested in broadening their horizons and undertaking a rigorous and rewarding experience improving their Spanish skills.
Wide arrange of topics from triage to diabetes symptoms and treatments to bioethics. And of course, lots of Spanish grammar and vocabulary.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments:
This course's greatest strength is Profesora Carreras. She is kind, devoted, engaging and a wonderful professor. Truly a gem of the Spanish department.

This course's weakness was student engagement. I truly think that a no laptops/iPads and an attendance policy would really improve student interaction. It's not that we don't find the course material interesting, it's that the temptation of screens is really hard to ignore. If it helps justify her decision, included below is a study that verifies the benefits of screen free note-taking for attention and memory.

The Pen Is Mightier Than the Keyboard: Advantages of Longhand Over Laptop Note Taking by Pam A. Mueller and Daniel M. Oppenheimer
https://journals.sagepub.com/doi/full/10.1177/0956797614524581
spanish for the medical professions
Professor Carreras is super nice and the homeworks were fair but this course could be improved with less lecturing and more opportunities to speak. Might be better as a slightly smaller class.

The strengths of this course are that it is largely independent and low-stakes. Profesora Carreras is great at harnessing conversation among students. The weaknesses of the course are that it can feel as though the content is disconnected.
more presentations

Strengths - easy 
weaknesses - boring
strengths = content; weaknesses = expectations, delivery

Strengths -- fun instruction, easy to follow
Weaknesses -- little feedback on written assignments
Professor was fantastic , she genuinely cares about the students and is always available for help. Maybe a more interactive teaching setting would be better than just lecturing .

The course is perfect as it is, I would not change a thing. Profesora Carreras has curated a diverse array of reading material that exposes us to different authors with different perspectives on current topics in science and medicine, while also providing us with many opportunities to share our own ideas in class.

strengths: fun class and lecture, homework level is just enough to stay engaged but not overbearing, facilitates organic language learning

weaknesses: interactive lecture makes people nervous to participate

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes, I highly recommend this course. It allows you to learn about terminology specific to the medical field and also about both historical and current topics in medicine. If you are a native speaker, this course will be incredibly easy yet still informative.

Yes, if you want to improve your Spanish in a low stress environment. Remember: what you get out of this course is what you put into it. Profesora is very forgiving, but if you take advantage of her kind nature you will learn a lot less in this course than you might have otherwise.
Yes, especially if you are concerned about finding an L5 that will not be too much work. I was worried I would be underprepared after testing into L5 but this class was *extremely* manageable.
Good spanish gut to one and done.
spanish for the medical professions
This is a fun class and you should take it if you need an L5 credit however I don't think my Spanish improved as much as it has in other L5 classes I have taken here.
I would recommend this course to another student. Its content is especially appealing for those on the premed track.
yes
Yes!
I recommend if you need an L5 to fulfill GLBL requirements but not if you actually want to learn for a certificate.
yes, it's a very interesting course that is easy to manage
Yes, I would -- it's a good Spanish class to take if you haven't taken one yet at Yale and you placed into L5
Yes! If you are looking for a lowkey L5 Spanish class with not much workload. 5th class option for sure.

I would absolutely recommend Profesora Carrerass class to any student interested in broadening their horizons and undertaking a rigorous and rewarding experience improving their Spanish skills. Profesora Carreras is not only an excellent teacher, but she is also an incredibly kind person who is rooting for each and every one of her students to excel and be the best speaker, writer, and thinker possible.
such a fun class! participation is worth a lot, but Professor Carreras won't even bat an eye if you make little grammar mistakes here and there
